greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Let a(n) be the least k such that in the prime power factorization of k! the exponents of primes p_1, ...,p_n are even, while the exponent of p_(n+1) is odd.
comment: The sequence is connected with a 1980-Erdős-Graham conjecture that, for every N, there exists an n such that in prime power factorization of n! at least N first exponents are even. In 1997, this conjecture was proved by D. Berend. A generalization was given by Y.-G. Chen (2003).
reference: P. Erdős, P. L. Graham, Old and new problems and results in combinatorial number theory, L'Enseignement Mathematique, Imprimerie Kunding, Geneva, 1980.
link: Giovanni Resta, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..46 (first 36 terms from Hiroaki Yamanouchi)
D. Berend, Parity of exponents in the factorization of n!, J. Number Theory, 64 (1997), 13-19.
Y.-G. Chen, On the parity of exponents in the standard factorization of n!, J. Number Theory, 100 (2003), 326-331.
program: (PARI) nbe(n) = {my(f = factor(n!)[, 2], nb = 0); for (i=1, #f, if (!(f[i] % 2), nb++, break);); nb;}
a(n) = {my(i = 1); while (nbe(i) != n, i++); i;} \\ _Michel Marcus_, Nov 07 2018
results.author: _Vladimir Shevelev_ and _Peter J. C. Moses_, Apr 07 2014
